channel.title: Learning Java Primitive Data Types
channel.description:
[b]Purpose[/b]: [i]To learn Primitive Data types and their values.[/i] [b]Can be used for[/b]: [i]A wide range of things very useful on a server.[/i] [b]Difficulty[/b]: [i]3-10 (Depends how fast you can learn)[/i] [b]Asumed Knowledge[/b]: [i]Knowledge of Understanding Java, and some C&P.[/i]
[size=14pt]Chapter One: Learning the Data Types:[/size]
There are quite some data types in the Language of Java, and I will be explaining what they are in this tutorial. Please read very careful, as this chapter maybe important. The following are all Data types:
[list]Primitive Data Types:
[ul][li]Byte[/li] [li]Short[/li] [li]Int[/li] [li]Long[/li] [li]Float[/li] [li]Double[/li] [li]Boolean[/li] [li]Char[/li] [li]String[/li][/ul]
Now that we have learned all of the Primitive Data Types usable in Java, I am now going to discuss what each one of them can do.
The [b]Byte[/b] is a signed two's integer. The byte data type can be used for storing bytes for memory, in cases such as arrays and other methods. The byte Data is also another form of hte [b]Int[/b]. When using [b]Byte[/b] you would you:
[code]public byte Name = 0;[/code]
However, there are different ways we could declare that, but we will not be discussing that in [b]This[/b] tutorial.
Next we have the [b]Short[/b]. The short is also another form of the [b]Int[/b]. The short can be used for storing Numeral Characters. However, the only different between [b]Short[/b] and [b]Int[/b] is that a Short can hold lesser value. To declare a [b]Short[/b], you would type:
[code]public short Name = 0;[/code]
Now we are at [b]Int[/b]. The Int is short for [b]Integer[/b]. An Int can be used for [b]Several[/b] things, and can be used for almost anything in Java. To declare an Int, simply type:
[code]public int Name = 0;[/code]
Now, we are at [b]Long[/b]. A long is a form of [b]Integer[/b], but can hold greater value then [b]Short[/b] or [b]Int[/b]. To declare this Data Type, you would type:
[code]public long Name = 0;[/code]
Ok, next of we have [b]Float[/b]. The float is a Single-Precision float point. Float is mainley used for savin Memory, however, it can be used otherwise. To declare, you would type:
[code]public float Name = 0;[/code]
Now we are at [b]boolean[/b]! The boolean is a variable used for true/false statements. It is only useful for flagging true/false in true/false conditions. You would declare by:
[code]public boolean Name = false[/code]
Next off, we have [b]Double[/b]. The [b]Double[/b] is another form of the [b]Float[/b]. The variable is good for decimal values or another numeral characters. To declare you would type:
[code]public double Name = 0;[/code]
Now we have [b]String[/b]. String is very useful. It can be used in cases to store text (In this case, Server's use Strings to store Usernames). You would type:
[code]public String Name = "";[/code]
Now let's go to Chapter [b]Two[/b], for learning the range of values.
[size=14pt]Chapter Two: Learning the Data Type Values of Range:[/size]
[b]Byte[/b] can hold a minimum of [b]-128[/b] and a Maximum of [b]127[/b]. [b]Short[/b] can hold a minimum of [b]-32768[/b] and a Maximum of [b]32767[/b]. [b]Int[/b] can hold a minimum of [b]-2147483648[/b] and a Maximum of [b]2147483647[/b]. [b]Long[/b] can hold a minimum of [b]-9223372036854775808[/b] and a Maximum of [b]9223372036854775807[/b]. [b]Char[/b] cam hold a minimum of [b]\u0000[/b] (or) [b]0[/b] and a Maximum of [b]\uffff[/b] (or) [b]65535[/b].
Thanks for reading my tutorial :) I hope all of you find this useful, as it did for me when I was a beginner. If you have any questions, [b]PM Me, Comment, or E-Mail at Kay652009@yahoo.com[/b].

item.title: Learning Java Primitive Data Types
item.dc:creator: @Ms_Kay Ms. Kay
item.description:
@Ms_Kay wrote:

Purpose: To learn Primitive Data types and their values.
Can be used for: A wide range of things very useful on a server.
Difficulty: 3-10 (Depends how fast you can learn)
Asumed Knowledge: Knowledge of Understanding Java, and some C&P.

[size=14pt]Chapter One: Learning the Data Types:[/size]

There are quite some data types in the Language of Java, and I will be explaining what they are in this tutorial. Please read very careful, as this chapter maybe important. The following are all Data types:

[list]Primitive Data Types:

[ul][li]Byte[/li]
[li]Short[/li]
[li]Int[/li]
[li]Long[/li]
[li]Float[/li]
[li]Double[/li]
[li]Boolean[/li]
[li]Char[/li]
[li]String[/li][/ul]

Now that we have learned all of the Primitive Data Types usable in Java, I am now going to discuss what each one of them can do.

The Byte is a signed two’s integer. The byte data type can be used for storing bytes for memory, in cases such as arrays and other methods. The byte Data is also another form of hte Int. When using Byte you would you:

public byte Name = 0;

However, there are different ways we could declare that, but we will not be discussing that in This tutorial.

Next we have the Short. The short is also another form of the Int. The short can be used for storing Numeral Characters. However, the only different between Short and Int is that a Short can hold lesser value. To declare a Short, you would type:

public short Name = 0;

Now we are at Int. The Int is short for Integer. An Int can be used for Several things, and can be used for almost anything in Java. To declare an Int, simply type:

public int Name = 0;

Now, we are at Long. A long is a form of Integer, but can hold greater value then Short or Int. To declare this Data Type, you would type:

public long Name = 0;

Ok, next of we have Float. The float is a Single-Precision float point. Float is mainley used for savin Memory, however, it can be used otherwise. To declare, you would type:

public float Name = 0;

Now we are at boolean! The boolean is a variable used for true/false statements. It is only useful for flagging true/false in true/false conditions. You would declare by:

public boolean Name = false

Next off, we have Double. The Double is another form of the Float. The variable is good for decimal values or another numeral characters. To declare you would type:

public double Name = 0;

Now we have String. String is very useful. It can be used in cases to store text (In this case, Server’s use Strings to store Usernames). You would type:

public String Name = "";

Now let’s go to Chapter Two, for learning the range of values.

[size=14pt]Chapter Two: Learning the Data Type Values of Range:[/size]

Byte can hold a minimum of -128 and a Maximum of 127.
Short can hold a minimum of -32768 and a Maximum of 32767.
Int can hold a minimum of -2147483648 and a Maximum of 2147483647.
Long can hold a minimum of -9223372036854775808 and a Maximum of 9223372036854775807.
Char cam hold a minimum of \u0000 (or) 0 and a Maximum of \uffff (or) 65535.

Thanks for reading my tutorial I hope all of you find this useful, as it did for me when I was a beginner. If you have any questions, PM Me, Comment, or E-Mail at Kay652009@yahoo.com.
